awd_titl_txt: EAGER: Algorithmic Approaches for Developing Markets
awd_abstract_narration:
Markets are systems that allocate scarce resources to individuals, coordinate aggregate behavior, and determine societal outcomes. Research on the design of markets has impacted the FCC spectrum auctions, the National Residency Matching Program, and school choice programs, among others.  The goal of this project is to bring similar fruit to bear on so-called developing markets that primarily serve poor and disadvantaged participants. The project will use two distinct markets, each with their own theoretical and practical challenges, as examples of this research agenda. The first is an agricultural market in Uganda. The goal of this market is to find an efficient set of trades among subsistence farmers and buyers. The second is an insurance market in Thailand. The goal of this market is to build a system of lending and borrowing for villagers. In addition to improving the lives of those who are impacted by developing markets, found all over the world, the project will provide opportunities for graduate and undergraduate students to participate in the research, as well as a rich interdisciplinary interaction between theoretical computer scientists and development economists.

Developing markets present unique challenges to a market designer, and present an opportunity to advance the state-of-the-art in market design. The primary challenge is an informational one: due to technological constraints, the designer has significantly less knowledge of and access to the underlying economic environment than is typically assumed. Populations in these markets often have urgent need for access to capital, while also being highly transitory. Both these factors push markets to clear rapidly. This, however, sacrifices market thickness and so degrades the quality of market outcomes. This project considers techniques to address this, including allocation schemes that incorporate stochastic assumptions about market participants. A secondary challenge concerns the need for simplicity and transparency.  Given that, such populations are understandably suspicious of outside interventions, and lack access to technologies that help them optimize their strategies within a market, the mechanisms in this project will be designed to be easy to comprehend and easy to play, including restricting the design space to a subclass of mechanisms that closely approximate the optimal one.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Markets are systems that allocate scarce resources to individuals, coordinate aggregate behavior and determine societal outcomes. The goal of this project was to develop markets that primarily serve the developing world. These markets encounter difficult issues, primarily around scarce and unreliable information, that necessitate the development of new theories and tools. This project provided those theories and tools. One arm of the project developed markets for subsistence farmers in sub-Saharan Africa. Another arm considered markets for credit with applications in rural Thailand and the Congo. 

The first arm of the project considered markets for subsistence farmers.  Subsistence farmers face challenges both in finding buyers for their extra goods, and guaranteeing the quality of their crops. Both these challenges fundamentally stem from an informational issue -- farmers lack data about prices and demand for their goods and, simultaneously, buyers lack knowledge about how much effort farmers exert in growing and high-quality crops.  To help farmers gain information about demand for their products, we designed a centralized market for bids and asks.  The design of this market required significant innovations in online matching as both bids and asks appear in the system over time.  We were able to develop provable guarantees in this domain by assuming a random arrival process of bids and asks. Our results have implications for other dynamic matching applications and have already been further developed in several recent papers from other research groups. To study methods for helping buyers develop trust in farmers, we focused on markets for carbon credits, a market notorious for fraud.  Afforestation by farmers can provide sought-after carbon credits, but only if farmers exert the high effort required to grow seedings on their farms to maturity.  Our proposed contract design maximizes carbon removal given a fixed budget for growing trees in an incentive-robust manner. That is, we guarantee it is in a farmer's best interest to exert high effort. We do so by designing a contract that front-loads a few high payments, but then issues nearly flat payments until the tree reaches maturity (at which point it is self-sustaining). The front-loaded payments encourage farmers to start the program while the flat payments encourage them to continue to the end.  The project contains a theoretical proposal as well as a simulation based on survey data. Our project is likely to have applied impact as well: we have been approached by an afforestation group at a major bank to discuss implementations of our design.

The second arm of the project considered credit markets.  Access to credit is a significant problem for people in developing nations. Lenders are hesitant to offer credit lines due to difficulties predicting default rates stemming from a lack of data. When detailed data is available (as is becoming increasingly common with new technologies like cell phones), lenders cherry-pick reliable borrowers, shutting down access to the most desparate. We addressed these challenges by studying the design of lending markets, as well as the collection of reliable data instruments. On the theoretical side, we studied a model of lending in information rich environments with an intermediary and showed that information can decrease welfare due to adverse selection.  We then developed some general principles of optimal information disclosure (i.e., appropriately coarsening data to increase access).  We applied our framework to data from rural credit markets in Thailand. In another theoretical project, we focused on designing transparent lending algorithms.  We develop a “learning to decide” approach for loans that provides transparency to the end user, in that it continues to support good recourse advice for those who do not receive a loan. This provides a new kind of regularization during the training pipeline. Our preliminary results, based on non-linear ground truth models as well as input censoring that results from loans not being made to some consumers, shows that we are able to improve on transparency, as measured through consistent and informative recourse advice, while still improving profit to the lender during online learning. Finally, in an applied project, we are collaborating with the United Nations (UN) in the Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC) to develop machine learning models for estimating household poverty using mobile phone and mobile money data. Generated passively, at very high frequency, and in large quantities, this suggests the possibility of a reliable and up-to-date source of data. At the same time, predictive models have been found to suffer low accuracy and especially for rural areas, and model brittleness. In our work, we use survey data to improve the accuracy of these predictive models.

The project had great impact outside its research results as well.  It provided opportunities for minority graduate and undergraduate students to participate in research, including one Black and one female graduate student, and one female undergraduate student. All students were provided with mentoring, networking and career-building opportunities.
